text: Draft at First Draft in Chicago. An outstanding dubbel, maybe a dubbel - stout hybrid. Lots of fig, date, sherry, and oaky bourbon. Sweet boozy finish.

On tap at El Bait Shop. Brown/black appearance with a tan head. Aroma of roasted grain, caramel malt, fruity esters, light vanilla and a hint of toasted oak. Similar flavor, rich, malty and lightly fruity with a bittersweet finish. The barrel aging aspect seems light, adding minor complexities. Maybe not a traditional Dubbel in the sense, but its top notch in that style category.

Draft at Elijah Ps. Its been some time since I had the original and really liked it. This looks like that one being dark brown and opaque. Bourbon dominates the aroma. I like when a really good beer is improved and the bourbon barrel aging does that. Vanilla, wood, and that regular Hell Hath that is so good. A winner of a beer.

Pours a dark brown amber almost black color with a small off-white head. Has a strong malty bourbon and vanilla aroma. Has a sweetish malty caramel and dark fruit flavor with hints of vanilla and bourbon. Has a slightly sweetish malty spicy dark fruit finish with vanilla and bourbon in the aftertaste.

On tap at Champps in Brookfield for their anniversary party. Congrats Champps! Almost black pour. Solid barrel presence. Not a ton much else with this one, but that is fine. Little "dubbel-ish" presence. Really nice barrel, though. 14

Draft. Nose is moderately phenolic with a light bourbon aroma. Faint wood not much vanilla. Nearly black pour. Small khaki head. Taste is boizy to start with a light fig and raisin flavor. Light pepper but way less phenolic than aroma would indicate. Subtle warming. Not bad. Barrel and base beer seem good but not grate.

Draft. Not a fan of this beer really on its own. But the barrel aging they did here reminds me of central waters. Tastes like elijah craig barrels for whatever reason. It is sweet and fruity but with a nice cinnamon vanilla overtone, good brew.
Tap at gravity. Near black with small head. Fairly strong bourbon over a solid dubbel. Toffee and oak. Light vanilla. A bit boozy, but very tasty.
Sample at Strong Ale Fest 2016. Comes dark brown with an average sized tan head. Aroma of fruit, bourbon, and vanilla. Taste is dark fruit, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and malt. Nice.

draft at drakes, poured a very dark brown to black with small oily mocha head. oak, vanilla, hints of cinnamon, bourbon. roasted malts chocolate all in one glass and it was delicious. the flavor was an ambrosia of stout and all its delicious goodies. as noted above in the nose all those scents came out in the flavor and it was so good. I could have sat there all day sipping on that.
On tap at Drakes. Pours black with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is strong wood, vanilla, bourbon, cocoa. Medium body, roast, cocoa, vanilla, light booze, creamy, very good.

On draft at Roll Out the Barrel 2016. The pour is a dark brown, shocking, with a thick ring of light tan head and no lace. The aroma is full of caramel and dark fruits. There is a string bourbon barrel in it, and its a bit messy. The flavor is just as messy. There is a Belgian malt in front of the bourbon barrel and a stereotypical dubbel. Its not that good. Caramel malts, lots of candy, Im just not a fan. The mouth feel is thin and light with a watery feel and a lack of carbonation. The aftertaste is roasty and caramely with a heavy bourbon. Not good
Excellent beer. Pours a very dark brown almost black. Aromas are bourbon, vanilla, dried fruit, sweet pastry. Flavours are nice and sweet. Bourbon, vanilla, dried fruit. Awesome.

Draft to taster. Looks good; a translucent fuller brown with beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells solid; date, raisin, oak, and a touch of vanilla. Tastes like it smells with a pleasant medium full-bodied mouthfeel. A good take on the style.

On tap at World of Beer (Charlottesville, VA). Aromas of vanilla, American oak, some spice, raisin, tree bark, caramel. Dark bronze with a fairly lasting beige head. Pretty sweet, vanilla, cocoa, raisin, woodsy. Full bodied.

Draft at Snallygaster 2016. Poured a dark brown, but not totally dark color with a small off-white head. Aroma was bourbon, woody vanilla notes, dried fruits and sweet roasted malts. Flavor is fruits, with a dose of chocolate, vanilla, wood. Pretty good.
6 oz pour on draft at Snallygaster 2016. Brown with tan head. Aromas of whiskey, oak, dark fruit, malt. Tastes of whiskey, dark fruit. Medium-full body with a dry finish.

Snallygaster. Medium beige head atop black body with brown edge. Aroma is moderately sweet, Bourbon/vanilla, some caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, Bourbon, some vanilla, light alcohol warming. Sticky medium-full body, light alcohol burn.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of frothy fine to large sized brown colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a very softly carbonated opaque except at the edges dark black brown colored body and a good lacing. The mild aroma was dark malt burnt malt and bourbon. The mildly vinous mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a lingering mild roasted malt aftertaste. The yummy flavor contained notes of roasted malt vanilla vinous burnt malt brown malt dark malt and hops. A wonderful best in class brew.
Loss of barrel here, whcih kills thr subtle greatness of this beer. Black pour with decent head and lacing. Light florals and smoke. Light sweet boozy finish. Tap at Churchkey.

I really was disappointed. Its a good beer to be sure but as a Belgium Double it doesnt make it. Pours almost black but for me it has way too much malt and too chocolaty. For the price, $15.00 a six pack, I was hoping for something better from Bells who are really my favorite brewer

Tasted on 11/26/11 from a 2009 bottle. Pours opaque black with a thin brown head that leaves a thin collar. The nose is bourbon, darkly roasted malt, and some spicy Belgian fruity notes. The flavor is a bit more tart fruit with the same darkly roasted malt and Belgian spice from nose, with a ton of more chocolate covered raisin, and just a touch of bourbon maple. The body is medium with light carbonation and a long chocolate covered raisin finish.

Old note from 8/11/09
Dark black pour light tan head with good lacing. Predominantly bourbon aroma some light sweet bread ho ey notes as well. Full creamy palate. A beer fighting with its barreling more separate than a comp,ex blend of flavors some light spice then bread then overwhelmed with bourbon. Nice but not great.

6/17/2010: Bells Bourbon Barrel Hell Hath No Fury... Aroma: Subtle licorice, smoke, and char; highly caramelized sugars. Appearance: Deep brown, opaque; thin beige head. Flavor: Bourbon soaked oak; black walnut; crystal malt sugars; barrel char; dry alcohol burn; slightly dry finish. Palate: Medium-bodied; smooth and mellow. Overall: Quite good with some complexity; the base beer is overwhelmed by the bourbon; would like to see a blend of regular Hell Hath No Fury and barrel-aged Hell Hath No Fury.
Growler fill (draught) shared by Danny at The Party Source in Bellevue, KY. Thanks! Rating #71 for this beer.

Name: Hell Hath no Furry, BA
Date: March 12, 2011
Mode: Growler
Source: Tasting
Appearance: opaque dark brown, fine beige head, drippy lace
Aroma: roasted malt aroma, good dose of hops, light oak melds well with the hops, touch of bourbon
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, touch of caramel sweetness grows into a candy character, light bitterness
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Very flowery Belgian Aroma, sweet and like a perfume. Color is a deep brown with red hues. Flavor is sweet, fruity. And a little spicy, definitely lots of potpourri and salt. Very Belgian. Almost some ketchup. 2009 bottle

tap. pours a copper brown with a descent off white bubbly head. aroma is caramel malt, oak, and some vanilla. flavor is the same as aroma. lacing is descent, beer is descent, but a bit over carbonated and is taking away from the flavor.

On tap at MBGSF 2011.  Pours a deep brown with a light tan head.  Bourbon aroma with brown sugar.  Flavor is also brown sugar and bourbon with dark fruit, though I cant quite describe it right.  Quite nice.

A deep dark ale with a thin creamy moka head. In aroma, a vinous and hoppy malt over vanilla beans. In mout, a woody vanilla chocolate malt with warming alcohol, light lactic notes, not bad but a bit off. On tap at Brewvvival, Feb. 26 2011.

A: Pours essentially black, maybe some reddish-brown highlights to it.  A small tan head sits on top.

S: Intense is a great way to describe this beer.  Really strong on the dark fruits up front, particularly plums, with a nice black cherry note to it as well.  The bourbon follows offering a pleasant booziness in addition to oak and vanilla aromas.  Just a touch of roasted malt (or perhaps charred oak) is in there.

T: Sweet malt, sugar, and dark fruits are there to remind you that this is a Belgian beer.  The plums are again quite strong and there is a touch of banana and raisin.  Bourbon barrel really provides a lot of the flavor and gives the beer a solid oak, vanilla, and booze profile.

M: Medium to full in body with a moderate carbonation.

D: This was quite a tasty beer.  I really thoroughly enjoyed it, but the booziness of it does get to you.

from the keg at Brewvival on 2/26/11.  black pour with a tan head.  nice bourbon nose with raisins and figs.  smooth body with some sweetness, more dark fruits, oak, and bourbon.  sweet finish with vanilla and oak.

Sampled @ Brewvival 2011.  Dark brown pour without much of a head.  Light bourbon aroma and some roasted malts.  Caramel and a light sweetness.  Flavors were roasty with notes of light bourbon and wood.  Somewhat of a tart and dry finish.  I liked it.
Sampled at Brewvival 2011.  Black pour with brown head. Slightly tart chocolate and bourbon vanilla.  Good stuff, but a little wierd.  lightly soured maybe?

On tap at a Bells Tap Takeover-pours a dark, almost black with a substantial tan head; bourbon smell is subtle & mixes with an almost woody aroma. Very malty taste with a subtle bourbon taste. A good beer!

At tap at the Bells Fermented Eclipse event at Stub and Herbs back in June. Fantastic event.

Pours near black with a nice tan head and a bit of lacing. Not too bad considering the heft on this. Nose is loaded with dark fruits, cherries, molasses, bourbon, and some fruity esters. Hints of roast going forward as well. The bourbon takes over the taste a bit and isnt as integrated as the nose, but still is quite good. Mouthfeel is full and fairly heavy, although not overly boozy. Drinks very well, and was one of my favorites of the event. Would like to try this again.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-06-2010

Growler shared with Unclejedi and company. Pours black with a dissipating brown head. Aroma of bourbon and cherry. Full bodied with a slick texture. Flavor dark roasted malts that is overpowered by Bourbon flavors (vanilla, oak, cherry) with a slightly above average residual sweetness. Some oak and tannins on the finish, but this is an example where the barrel overpowers the base beer too much- at least for me.

Sample from tap @ Party Source.  Pours a hazy dark brown color with a small creamy beige head.  The aroma is big bourbon, woody, sweetness from sugars and a touch of molasses and some yeastiness.  The flavor is moderately sweet malts, bourbon, woody with some biterness, chocolate and Belgian sugar. Medium bodied.

On tap at Firkin in Libertyville, IL. Pours a very deep brown colored body with a big, two finger-width, very dense and creamy, chocolate brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice, sticky lacing. Aroma has lots of perfumey, sweeter dark fruits with plums, raisins, and blackberries. A touch of tart green apple too. Some sweeter bourbon with a light oaky vanilla. Malts come out more as this warms with some light cocoas and a bit of a molasses sweetness. Flavor is similar. Very silky caramel malt up front with a light cocoa. Sweet bourbon presents itself cleanly and evenly throughout. More dark fruits with plenty of blackberries, plums, dates, and raisins along with just a touch of green apple tartness again. A slight vanilla joins the bourbon as this finishes very clean and smooth while slowly drying with a light woody bitterness, some Belgian yeast spice, and a hint of roast. Nice warming feel before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Medium, smooth body and a light-medium, soft carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid beer. The bourbon is well integrated with the flavors and this drinks nicely.

Deep brown black pour.  The nose is quite licorice-like.  Bitter chocolate and cocoa with a lot of heavy bourbony sweetness.  The heat and dirtiness of the original version has faded substantially.  Its pretty decent now with a mixture of dark fruit, plums and salty licorice with a lot of bourbon adding a sweet oaky/vanilla flavour before a lingering roastiness sets in to bring it together.  Big, brash and much better than the original.

Massive bourbon nose, lots of chocolate, molasses along with some lighter sugars. Taste is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, with buttery bourbon, a touch of coconut, some chocolate and lots of raw sugar.
On tap at sergios.  Pours very dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of oak, belgian yeast, and brown sugar.  Pretty good flavor for a double with a strong oak finish.  Alcohol apparent.  Very good.

Draft sample at the Michigan Brewers Guild Fall Fest.  Brown/black color with thin tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, wood, dark fruits, bready yeast, and molasses.  Taste is sweet, with rich, lightly carbonated mouthfeel.  Im a sucker for bourbon barrel beers, so I dug this one!

Draft. Poured an opaque black color with a brown head. Bourbon, wood, chocolate, and brown sugar in the nose. Full bodied and somewhat sweet. Boozy bourbon, molasses, brown sugar, and subdued vanilla and sassafras flavors. Good stuff.

Total blackness in the glass, nice brown ring above, slowly slipping down in size.
Aroma reeks of bourbon, Big molasses and vanilla, sweet, rich, and decadent. Cocoa and dark fruit below, a bit.
Taste: Succulent and sweet, juicy, palpably pulpy, rolls away and dries off some. Dark fruit, fig, raisin, dates, maybe...a wonderful port wine quality asserts itself. Realigns, edges into moderation, evens out, ends light and dry on the palate. Flavor still lingers lightly.
If theres a flaw in this, its that you cant really discern the character of the dubbel beneath the bourbon in this, but its too excellent a combination to quibble over such things. If you love bourbon barrel brews, this one does the trick. The base beer holds its own, and the bourbon truly shines.
So glad to try this one!
On tap at cfb in charleston. Smells like baking bread.  Color is deep black, and flavor is similar to an imperial stout.  Bourbon aging makes this very sour.  Delicious!  This was a party in my mouth
Near black with an off white head. Vanilla, oak, bourbon nose. Similar flavor with some tart green apples and chocolate. A touch of twangy sourness and a thinner body for the finish. Interesting.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2013 On tap at Mekong for the 15th Anniversary Party on 08/19/2010. Dark black body with a small tan head. Big yeast and roast aroma. Big bourbon, yeast, roast, chocolate and malt flavor. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. 8/4/8/3/15

Sampled on tap at the Louisville Beer Store. The appearance is a medium dark brown that was very clear. The aromas had a full malt bouquet, with spice accents, and bourbon. The flavors rolled in a similar line. The bourbon notes are oaky and accent the malts well. Almost some rye flavors to is. A little more medium in body. A solid brew but a touch under expectations but nice.

Tap @ HopCat for RBSG10 - dark black pour. Arouma is molasses, bitter chocolate and vanilla with a hint of coconut. Very aroumatic, dark chocolate, bourbony and woody. Finishes bitter and boozer on the tounge. Creamy body with espresso.

Draft at a Bells tasting at Harris Grill, Pittsburgh, PA.

Poured a lovely BLACK with tan head and ruby highlights.  Aroma was a relative disappointment, probably too cold, but still came through with loads of smoke, cherries, blackberries and caramel.

Body followed with similar flavors without too much bourbon!  I cant say how much I appreciated the subtleties of the bourbon adding good caramel and smoke flavors.

Palate was fairly good, they also avoided the astringent viscosity that most in this style find, which I am most appreciative of.

Overall another winner from Bells!

Draft at HopCat during RBSG 10.  Dark near black.  Nice combo of bourbon and coffee, light roast, light Belgian yeast, like this much more than the non-barreled version, a bit cola-like.  A bit syrupy with nice fizzy carbonation.

Draft RBSG 2010 Pours pitch black with little to no head. The bouquet is a swirl of maple syrup, coconut, bourbon, vanilla and pecan praline. Full-bodied and silky with stinging carbonation. The flavor provides rich caramel, praline, mocha, pouch tobacco, coconut, bourbon and restrained - but warming - ethanol. Hearty, mocha, lightly boozy finish.

On tap at HopCat while in town for RBSG.  Pours a ruby crimson black with a thin beige head.  Soft toffee and roast.  Milky, chocolate and caramel.  Toast and roast, coffee.  More coffee on the finish, long and roasty.

Draft at Hopcat during RBSG. The bourbon in this one take it for a ride. Standard dubbel at the base, translucent auburn with offwhite head that dissipates. Nose has a strong element of booze and vanilla. Taste is dark fruits, light cherry and plum notes fading into spicy phenols from the Belgian strain. An improvement over the standard HHNF. Okay.

Draught at HopCat, RBSG 2010. Aroma and flavors of fruit, mostly plums and raisins, chocolate, port, along side the bourbon and caramel. Alcohol noticeable. Lots of plum and raisin. Decent, but weird for a dubbel to me.

On tap during RBSG at Hopcat. Poured a near black with a near brown head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma was very fruit forward with light fruits such as apples present with bourbon and caramel as well. Flavor started with some light fruits with bourbon. The bourbon grows as does a caramel and sweet grain note.

Draft at The Hopcat, during the Bells Night for RBSG. Pours black, nearly opaque, thin head, poor lacing. Nose is bourbon, red and black fruit, quite soft, but very rich, some toffee, brown malt. Very fruit-forward flavour profile, backed by the bourbon, nippy and a bit spicy, but this tasted a bit hot to me, I wish I hadnt gotten a full pint. Cool and complex but not terribly drinkable.

On tap at Hopcat (Grand Rapids, MI). Hopcat 25 Bells tap event for RBSG kickoff! Pours a nice dark opaque brown, almost blackish, with a brownish small head that dies to a film, laces lightly. Aromas are a touch of brown sugar, slight dubbel Belgian yeast, a decent dose of bourbon and vanilla tannins, wet oak, a bit sweet but mellow. Initial is thicker bodied, a moderate dose of bourbon and vanilla tannins, touch of booziness, brown sugar, caramel malts, decent Belgian yeast. Fairly bourbon barrel forward. Nice tannins, sufficient booziness, good Bourbon flavor. Takes over the character of the base a bit much, but still wonderful

Served on draft at Hopcat in Grand Rapids and shared by someone. Pours a dark brown color with a medium head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of plum, whisky, toffee and apple. The taste is toffee, bourbon, light fruity notes and a faint bit of chocolate. Medium bodied. Nice.

Looks like an RIS. Lots of cherry. Fairly similar to their cherry stout on a good day really. Not at all a dubbel, but whatev, still tasty. Rich chocolate. Nice hop bitterness in the finish. There is some bourbon in the aroma, and it lends a sweet damp woody character.

Pours deep brown with thin off white head, aroma is big sweet caramel, molasses and some nuts with a nice bourbon character.  Big sweet caramel, toffee, molasses, nuts and bourbon in the beginning fade to a nice sweet and dry oaky finish.  Complex and delicious!

Draft @ FoBAB 2009, Chicago, IL. Pours a dark brown amber almost black color with a small off-white head. Has a strong malty bourbon and vanilla aroma. Has a sweetish malty caramel and dark fruit flavor with hints of vanilla and bourbon. Has a slightly sweetish malty spicy dark fruit finish with vanilla and bourbon in the aftertaste.

Strong boozy bourbon notes in the aroma. Doesnt burn, though. Wow, lots of bourbon flavour. Pretty overpowering. I can still get some of the hell hath no fury base out of it, but the bourbon is string with this one. Body is a bit thin. Finishes dry and woody.
Solid with LOTS of bourbon and vanilla.  On tap at a Bells fest.  It actually tastes like a stout base to me, not an Abbey Dubbel or any kind of belgian.  Nice though!

Tap at Bells City TAP House event PBW10. Pours a deeper brownish amber with a medium off white head.  Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, oak, coconut, dark fruits and Belgian spicy/fruity yeast esters.  Flavor of the same.   Bourbon was nicely balanced and complimented the beer.

Pours a deep impenetrable  brown, almost a black color with a tight small head. The aroma is all sorts of sweet but has a lot of things that blend very well together some maple syrup, vanilla, some brown sugar with some faint roastiness and some apple. The flavor is not as sweet as the aroma but its not a dry beer either. Right up front there are notes of strong nuttiness and some distinct but pleasant booziness. There is certainly some bourbon flavor here but its not over bearing and the vanilla and oak blend very well with the brown sugar and burnt notes along with the earthiness and the cherry fruitiness. The palate is silky and full, and
I enjoyed the heck out of this one. Honestly if the flavor hadnt mysteriously "fallen off" 3/4 the way through the glass the rating would be higher.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2011 Jesus Christ Bobby! A thick black pour with a thin tan head. Aromas of bourbon, chocolate, yeast and caramel. Vanilla and bourbon flavors dominate with a fruity and slightly alcohol finish. Good, but not quite my "cup of tea". Had this again on tap 2/27/11; slight sourness to it.

Draft at Bells Fermented Eclipse at Stub & Herbs.  Pours a pitch black body with light brown head.  Aroma of belgian yeasts/malts, bourbon, cocoa, and dark fruits.  Flavor is similar with a strong vanilla and coconut taste along with roasted malts.  There is also a strong bourbon flavor, but tends to mellow as it warms.  Thick, smooth mouthfeel with a bourbon and dark fruit finish.

[Tap] Pours basically black with a small tan head. Wow, the barrel just completely overtook this beer. I wasnt expecting much in the first place since the base beer wasnt terribly impressive either, but this is just really over-barreled. Flavor and aroma of sweet caramel, tons of vanilla, coconut, and some alcohol. Sweet, syrupy mouthfeel and not too much else.

Growler sample shared by Danny at Party Source. Poured dark brown color with minimal off-white frothy head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate to heavy malty, woody, bourbon, yeast aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy bourbon sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Standout brew.

Draft at the Brickstore. I love you guys. At first it was served a bit too cold and the bourbon was a little off putting. As it warmed though it was liquid goodness. An incredible vanilla flavor with a touch of bourbon alcohol up front. That fades into a malty nutty rich mouth coating experience. The finish leaves you with a slight sweetness and touch of fruit. Complex where each sip gives you a different element. Really nice drink here.

draft at City Tap House for their "Bells 31 Flavors" event.
Poured a very dark brown with caramel-colored edges and a mocha two-finger head which dissapated quickly to a frothy coating. Nose is Dark fruits, Belgian yeast and sweet malt. The taste is roasted malt up front followed by dark fruits, vanilla and the brown, sugar-like sweet malt. There is also evidence of the yeast and some spice. Mouthfeel is medium, smooth - not a lot of carbonation evident, and very dry. This is a nice, comfortable brew and I liked the level of warmth and influence of the bourbon barrel. A good sipper for sure but the dryness might not argue for making it session-able for me.
This beer almost had the texture of liquid molasses, that may not sound appealing but it was amazing.  Its aged for months in bourbon barrels which brings out the strong vanilla and coconut flavors.

Served on draft at Jose Pistolas.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque with a massive three finger dark mocha head that slowly fades into a lasting cap. Minimal spots of lacing left behind.

Sweet malty aroma with a huge bourbon character in the nose. Slight earthy oak and vanilla from the barrel aging complimen the bourbon and dark malt notes. Hints of dark fruit and subtle spice. Picking up tart dark cherry, fig and plum. So far this beer looks and smells amazing.

Incredibly smooth drinking with the perfect amount of sweet bourbon and heat balancing out the dark raster malt notes and sweet tart dark fruit. Chewy and slightly viscous with zesty peppery spice and alcohol heat. As in he aroma, the barrel aging adds complexity giving off hi ts of vanilla and earthy oak. This beer is incredibly complex and even though the bourbon gives off some heat and warmth in the finish, the ABV is decently masked, making this dangerously drnkable. Highly recommnded!!!!

[Draft @ Jose Pistolas] Hazy purple brown color with a small, light tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of bourbon, wood, raisins, vanilla, a bit of cocoa, and alcohol.  Taste of dark fruits, raisins, wood, brown sugar, charred wood, and a bourbony alcohol finish.

dark, viscous-looking brown with a thin tan head. vinous, port nose with strong bourbon coming across. lighter mouthfeel than expected, with substantial alcohol warming. lots of bourbon, dark fruit, hints of molasses and smoke.

Tap at hopcat, gr mich. Ruddy brown body with small brown head. Aroma of huge bourbon, toffee, alcohol and chocolate. Overpowered by bourbon, as is the flavor.  Sweet bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, hot hops and alcohol. Caramelized sugar and raison as well.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Deep, murky brown body, tight tan head. Nose of potent bourbon and buttery oak with chocolate, plum, pear and a hint of pickle. Bourbon-dominated body, hot, with vanilla and tannic oak in addition to chocolate, prune, licorice, and spices from the base beer. The barrel aging shifted the emphasis of this beer to the bourbon and oak, with mixed results; some of the subtleties of the beer were lost to the tannic booziness.

on tap at Maduro for the Bells party, pre GTMW....pours dark caramel brown with a medium tan head....nose is loaded with green apple, yeast, and dark fruit... flavors are again green apple, yeasty, with raisin and bourbon. this never came together too well.
A very rich abbey dubbel. Almost too rich, but very complex and well balanced.

Sampled at the 10 MBGWF.  Deep mahogany pour with a small brown head.  Vinous dark fruit aroma with rich heavy charred oak and smoky bourbon.  The flavor has loads of ripe dark fruit, tobacco and a soft balance of vanilla and oak.  Creamy full body with soft carbonation.

On draught at the Happy Gnome in St. Paul, Minnesota. Pours a near black opaque colored brew with a thick off-white head that slowly dissipates to a creamy top. Aroma of bourbon, coconut, chocolate, a hint of toasted dark malt, candi sugar and some dry raisin. Taste is medium bodied with the bourbon over-powering the Belgian dubbel character. Finish is a touch rough and the bourbonization may be overpowering. At least it will make the bourbon fans happy.

Tap at the Happy Gnome, St Paul.  Black color with a large head.  Light malt, herbal and fruity aroma.  Bourbon taste up front, though not too strong.  Light wood and dark candi sugar.  A little molasses.  Quite grainy.

Growler from miketd

I believe mike shared this in lieu of his presence at the start of a winter tasting.  The bourbon was a bit much for my tastes making me think this one needs time to settle (if that is possible).  If you like bourbon bombs hunt it down.  Otherwise you will still find a solid release that enhances an already amazing beer but it wont be like some of the other Bells barrel aged releases.

Aroma / Appearance - The body looks like Hell Hath No Fury except maybe a bit more sluggish and flat.  Whether this was due to the age of the growler or the beer itself is hard to say.  It definitely is different in appearance than an imperial stout (more brownish) but still murky and dark.  The nose was a little too rich in bourbon for my tastes.  I would have liked it toned down and this would have instantly been my favorite beer of the night.  As it is I would love to give this another try at the Beer Engine or somewhere else for a special event.

Flavor / Palate - The mouthfeel was thick and chewy.  For the profile of the base beer see my other rating.  This one adds a heavy bourbon aspect that borders on cloying.  A growler alone would be a tough challenge.  I think in the end this is a beer that is well made but suffers a little from the "everything barrel aged" approach that has been making the rounds for the last few years.

Growler shared by George.  Thanks George!  Pours black/dark brown with tan head.  Aroma is dark fruit, nail polish, vanilla, booze, and yeast.   The aroma is really hard to take.  It simply doesnt smell that good.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose and is a bit better.  In other words, it tastes better than it smells.  Hard liquor upfront with vanilla, yeast, dark fruit, and nail polish meld together.  I think the barrel used must have been a sour mash whiskey because thats what it tastes like.  Just a little too boozy for me overall and I really like the boozy ones.  Just not this one.  Its average.

Sample at the Dude-a-Thon at Studio 35 (and then a couple pints out of a growler at a friends house) on 1/17/10. Pour is pitch black with a medium tan head. Nose is vanilla and bourbon with some chocolate and fruit. Bourbon and vanilla hit the tongue first with the chocolate creeping in on the back end. The Belgian aspects of this beer are kinda getting masked by the barrel-aging and I couldnt be happier. Tasty stuff!

Sample at the Bells/Lebowski Dude-A-Thon at Studio 35 on 01/17/10. The beer is a muddy dark brown color with a thin tan head that recedes steadily. Stringy lacing. Tart fruit, bourbon and dark malt in the nose. Rich body with flavors of ripe fruit, oaky bourbon, malt and yeast. The finish is vanilla and oak with a fruity aftertaste. Pretty good all around.
FoBAB.  Pours brown.  Still a relatively sweet brew.  Dark fruit in the flavor and aroma, bourbon, and the Belgian yeast.  Interesting.

Sampled at FoBAB 09.  Murky brown pour with a tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, nuts, coffee, dark fruit.  Flavor is pretty nice.  The bourbon and the nuttiness of the dubbel meshed well.  Irish coffee finish.  Pretty cool one off beer to try.

FoBAB.  Dark messy looking brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is nutty, coffee, and dark fruits.  Flavor is a bit sweeter than expected with nutty/ fruity notes.  A bit of bourbon and coffee in the finish.  Interesting

on tap at Maduro preGTMW party. pours dark brown with tan head. nose is loaded with green apple, belgian yeast. flavors are again green apple, yeasty, with raisin and bourbon. this never came together to well.

(Draught)  Pours an opaque dark brown (near black) body with a small tan head.  Aroma of bourbon, dates, and vanilla.  Flavor of bourbon, dates, Belgian yeast, raisins, and vinous with a dry oak finish.

Tap at Maduro.  Pours to a near black/tan head.  Subtle sweet dubbel malts and yeasts with light vanilla.  Sweet cereal malts meets vanilla and dubbel yeasts.  Charred oak.  Rich creamy mouthfeel with some sweet bourbon.  Weird, but I thought it may have been better than the regular.

On tap at Maduro.  Poured medium-viscosity deep brown with a creamy, easily-resuscitated dark tan head.  The aroma picked up sour apricot and other fruity notes over some darker herbal and odd yeasty character.. bourbon and toasted oak accents.. interesting, but just OK.  The flavor was tangy with the expected sourness from the nose (but sporting more pear than apricot).. bourbon was light overall, but building and spicy.. darker Belgian-inspired yeast in there too.. nice hit of chocolate on the back.  Medium-plus bodied with a creamy middle, but too much sourness and astringency.. this either didnt take well to the barrel or it needs more aging time outside the barrel.
